channel.title: NYT > International Home
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Susan Collins of Maine Says She Will Not Vote for Donald Trump
item.media:description: Senator Susan Collins spoke at a news conference in Washington in June.
item.description: The senator’s announcement was another blow to Mr. Trump as he tries to unite his party and win more support from women.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDER BURNS

item.title: Mormons’ Distaste for Donald Trump Puts Utah Up for Grabs
item.media:description: “The issue of religious liberty is an important one in the state, and the notion of a religious test for immigration raises deep concerns,” said Chris Karpowitz, an associate professor at Brigham Young University.
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.description: With their own history of facing religious bias, Mormons in reliably Republican Utah are worried about whether to support a nominee who denigrates Muslims.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)

item.title: Introducing The Run-Up, Our New Election Podcast
item.description: It’s 90 days until the election. Twice a week on our new podcast, the campaign team at The Times will make sense of the final, delirious phase of the campaign.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL BARBARO

item.title: Donald Trump Adopts G.O.P. Tax Cuts, but Balks at Trade Pacts
item.description: Mr. Trump sought to move beyond a week of turmoil, turning his attention to the economy with a speech in which he cast himself as a president who could create new jobs.
item.dc:creator: NEIL IRWIN and ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: Parents of 2 Americans Killed in Benghazi Attack Sue Hillary Clinton
item.media:description: Patricia Smith, whose son was killed in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012, spoke at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland in July.
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: In a wrongful-death lawsuit filed on Monday, the parents claim that Mrs. Clinton’s use of a private email server was a cause of the 2012 attack.
item.dc:creator: AMY CHOZICK

item.title: Putin and Erdogan, Both Isolated, Reach Out to Each Other
item.description: The Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is visiting his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, to discuss Syria and trade.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and TIM ARANGO
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Putin and Erdogan Meet for Talks
item.description: President, Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey met in St. Petersburg on Tuesday to talk about diplomatic relations between the two countries.

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: In the Olympic Pool, Contempt for Drug Cheats Rises to the Surface
item.media:description: Lilly King of the United States after winning the women’s 100-meter breaststroke final Monday at the Rio Games, setting an Olympic record with a time of 1 minute 4.93 seconds.
item.description: Swimmers at the Rio Games who once served suspensions for doping have been openly vilified by their rivals, creating plenty of awkwardness.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER CLAREY and KAREN CROUSE

item.title: Live From Rio: Biles, Phelps, Hosszu and Ledecky in Spotlight
item.description: Here’s our daily roundup of what happened, and what is going to happen, at the Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro.
item.dc:creator: SAM MANCHESTER

item.title: American Lilly King Makes Statement With Olympic Record in 100-Meter Breaststroke
item.media:description: Lilly King of the United States won the gold medal in the 100-meter breaststroke on Monday in Olympic-record time, beating Yulia Efimova of Russia.
item.description: Yulia Efimova, King’s rival who served a 16-month doping suspension, secured silver.
item.dc:creator: KAREN CROUSE

item.title: Brazilians Speak Portuguese, but the Olympics Must Use French
item.media:description: Michaëlle Jean is the secretary general of the International Organization of la Francophonie. “It’s a struggle each time you have the Olympic Games, in a different country and a different city,” she said.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: A group is determined to make sure nobody forgets that French is one of the Olympics’ two official languages, along with English.
item.dc:creator: SARAH LYALL

item.title: Full Coverage of the Games
item.description: All the Rio news, results and interactive features that are fit to print.

item.title: Well: The Merits of Reading Real Books to Your Children
item.description: A small child cannot tap the duck in a board book and elicit a quack; for that, the child needs to turn to a parent.
item.dc:creator: PERRI KLASS, M.D.

item.title: Applied Science: Ready to Snap at Work? Get in Touch With Your Inner Animal
item.description: Breathing and posture techniques can help you tame your hard-wired fight-or-flight response, alleviating anxiety and improving clarity and creativity.
item.dc:creator: PHYLLIS KORKKI

item.title: Mexico’s Richest Man Confronts a New Foe: The State That Helped Make Him Rich
item.media:description: Carlos Slim, center, arriving for a meeting in Nicaragua last year. More than half of his cellphone company’s sales now come from outside Mexico.
item.description: Carlos Slim built a business empire that has made him one of the world’s richest men. But Mexico’s leaders have been chipping away at his domain with regulations.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED, RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Minorities Suffer From Unequal Pain Treatment
item.media:description: Roslyn Lewis of Tuscaloosa, Ala., injured her back while working at a dollar store. A decade later, the pain radiates to one of her knees and remains largely unaddressed.
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.description: Researchers cite several reasons for the disparity, including evidence of racial bias and stereotyping. The lower level of treatment tends to lead to more disability.
item.dc:creator: ABBY GOODNOUGH

item.title: Trilobites: A Warning for Dogs, and Their Best Friends, in Study of Fertility
item.media:description: Golden retriever puppies. The breed was among several in a study that were found to have declining sperm quality that could lead to fertility problems in the future.
item.description: Decreased sperm quality and other effects could be related to environmental causes, and further declines could harm the dogs’ ability to reproduce.
item.dc:creator: JAN HOFFMAN

item.title: ‘They Will Kill Us’: Afghan Translators Plead for Delayed U.S. Visas
item.media:description: Zar Mohammad Stanikzai at a relative’s home in Afghanistan. He is waiting for one of the thousands of visas set aside for the translators and interpreters who helped the United States military during the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.description: Translators, now facing Taliban threats, said the United States promised to keep them safe. Congress is bickering over the program meant to be their deliverance.
item.dc:creator: EMMARIE HUETTEMAN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Israel Accuses U.N. Worker of Aiding Hamas in Gaza
item.media:description: The United Nations Development Program headquarters in Gaza City. One of its engineers has been detained by Israel’s internal security agency.
item.description: Prosecutors say a United Nations Development Program engineer used his position to provide material assistance to the Islamist group and its military wing.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Itineraries: Delta Malfunction on Land Keeps a Fleet of Planes From the Sky
item.media:description: Delta Air Lines passengers waited in line at a ticket counter in Newark Liberty International Airport in New Jersey on Monday.
item.description: A cascade of delayed and canceled flights on Monday was the latest example of how a failure in an airline’s system can have catastrophic effects.
item.dc:creator: ANNALYN KURTZ

item.title: A 500-Square-Foot Area in Miami Is Ground Zero for the Zika Virus
item.media:description: A plane sprays pesticide over the Wynwood neighborhood of Miami in August, the second round of aerial spraying in the area.
item.description: Health officials are investigating 17 homegrown cases of the virus, including 13 in the Wynwood neighborhood of Miami.
item.dc:creator: PAM BELLUCK
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Saudi-Led Coalition Resumes Bombing of Yemeni Capital After Talks Collapse
item.description: Warplanes struck Sana, killing civilians, after the collapse of talks between Houthi rebels and the Saudi-backed government.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: ‘The Girl From Ipanema’ Goes Walking Again, With Gisele Bündchen’s Help
item.media:description: Heloísa Pinheiro in 2012. She was the muse for “The Girl From Ipanema.”
item.description: Thanks to the supermodel’s strut during the opening ceremony of the Rio Olympics, the 1963 bossa nova tune has found new life.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: Well: Need a Babysitter? Don’t Count On Grandma
item.media:description: Susan Glickman with her granddaughter, Lilah.
item.description: There’s often an undercurrent of ambivalence about being asked to help take care of grandchildren.
item.dc:creator: SHARON JAYSON

item.title: Here’s Lucy! ‘Scary’ Statue Is Replaced With One That Looks Like Her
item.media:description: The new statue of the actress Lucille Ball was unveiled on what would have been the comedian’s 105th birthday in Celoron, N.Y.
item.description: A widely mocked statue of Lucille Ball was replaced in her western New York hometown of Celoron on what would have been the comedian’s 105th birthday.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Speculation Ends: Date and Venue Set for World Chess Championship in New York
item.media:description: A chess board and a map of New York City at the headquarters of Chess in the Schools in Manhattan. The World Chess Championship is scheduled to begin on Nov. 11 at the South Street Seaport and continue for several weeks.
item.media:credit: Tom White for The New York Times
item.description: The tournament will be held at the South Street Seaport in Lower Manhattan starting in November, returning to the city for the first time in more than two decades.
item.dc:creator: JOHN LELAND

item.title: U.S. Mortality Rate Declines, and Researchers Breathe a Sigh of Relief
item.description: The death rate, a key indicator of the health of a nation, was propelled to an increase last year in part because of drug overdoses.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Letter From Europe: For Italians, Donald Trump’s Act Is Familiar
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi, center, in 2015. Much has been made in Italy of the similarities between Donald J. Trump and Mr. Berlusconi: Both glorify their success in business, both dominate the media landscape, both boast about their sexual prowess, and both seem to enjoy insulting people and nations.
item.description: ‘‘Tocca a voi’’ is a comment Italians often make to Americans now, meaning ‘‘It is your turn,’’ because Italy was once led by Silvio Berlusconi.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: What in the World: Who’s Got a Carrier to Rival the U.S. Navy’s? (Hint: Not Russia.)
item.media:description: The French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle has played a central role in carrying out airstrikes against the Islamic State in the Middle East.
item.description: To project striking power almost anywhere, it’s hard to beat a nuclear-powered aircraft carrier. Almost all of the 11 in existence are American — almost.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Facebook Blocks Ad Blockers, but It Strives to Make Ads More Relevant
item.media:description: As it blocks ad blockers, Facebook is asking its users to help control the ads they see on the site.
item.description: The programs that prevent websites from displaying ads will be rendered useless for those accessing the social network’s desktop site, but not on mobile browsers.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: De La Soul’s Legacy Is Trapped in Digital Limbo
item.media:description: From left, David Jolicoeur, Kelvin Mercer and Vincent Mason of the pioneering hip-hop group De La Soul.
item.description: The hip-hop pioneers have their first new album in 12 years, “And the Anonymous Nobody.” But if you want to hear their early work, look for CDs, vinyl and cassettes.
item.dc:creator: FINN COHEN

item.title: As Peat Bogs Burn, a Climate Threat Rises
item.media:description: A lightning storm in Utikuma Lake, Alberta, in June. The area was burned from the 2011 wildfire. After each fire, peat moss grows and accumulates carbon, building a new layer on top of the previous one.
item.media:credit: Ed Ou for The New York Times
item.description: Warming temperatures can dry out northern peatlands, increasing the risk of fires that release thousands of years of stored carbon into the atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Public Health: Obamacare Appears to Be Making People Healthier
item.media:description: Wanda Morrison, 61, of Louisville, Ky., with her physician, Dr. Kimberley Brumleve, at the Family Health Center in Louisville in November 2015.
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.description: A new survey of low-income people isn’t perfect, but it suggests that new health insurance options have improved people’s health.
item.dc:creator: MARGOT SANGER-KATZ
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
